answers.answer: Difficult to say without evaluation.Being a diabetic, checking your sugars on a regular basis should be done, as fluctuations and low levels can cause some of the disorientation you are feeling.Various neurological causes should also be evaluated for, including head imaging with a CT scan or MRI.  The carotid arteries should be looked at for blockages, and can be evaluated with an ultrasound.Finally, arrhythmias, or an abnormal heart rhythm, can lead to feelings of disorientation and pre-syncope.  If suspected, an echocardiogram as well as a Holter monitor should be performed.These options can be discussed with your personal physician, or in conjunction with a neurologist.This answer is not intended as and does not substitute for medical advice - the information presented is for patient education only. Please see your personal physician for further evaluation of your individual case.Kevin Pho, M.D.www.kevinmd.comwww.twitter.com/kevinmd

question: Occasionally I will get an 'out of body experience'.  It is preceded by a taste in my mouth or an odor in my nostrils.  I have an instant to think "NO, not again!" before I get chills and this out of body feeling.  It does not last long at all and does not happen often but if I have one, as I did at 6:30 am this morning, I will usually have several.  I have had 4 and it is now 9 am.  I am diabetic, but do not take any meds other than insulin.  This has been happening for a couple of years, since I had surgery for a sisk on my liver related to my diabetes.  I do not drink or do drugs, I cannot think what would cause this.  It is very upsetting since there is no warning.  I appreciate any help that you can offer.
title: Need cause for disorientation spells
